baseline_groups.claim_summary: Graduates from universities in severely recession-affected commuting zones experience lower median income post-recession (DiD: treat = post x badreccz is negative).
baseline_groups.notes: The baseline uses log median positive income (lnk_medpos), university + cohort FE, full controls, clustered at university level. The spec 'did/fe/twoway' is numerically identical to 'baseline' and is flagged as a duplicate. The paper also examines tier-level heterogeneity, but the primary estimand is the overall average DiD effect.

global_notes: 86 total specifications. 5 have missing/NaN coefficients due to collinearity or ill-defined single-arm samples (cz_x_cohort, pre_recession_cohorts, post_recession_cohorts, severe_cz_only, mild_cz_only). 10 heterogeneity interaction specifications change the treatment variable to an interaction term and are not direct tests of the core claim. 2 placebo specifications use fake treatment timing. 11 alternative outcome specifications use different income distribution measures. The core claim is well-supported with many valid robustness checks across controls, samples, FE structures, inference methods, and functional forms.
